Well, to be fair, the analogue to rpm is really dpkg, not apt.  But to clarify, while they are both "package managers" the dpkg system keeps track of far more information (with an exception I'll get to) in regards to package "state" information on disk.  For example, dpkg will keep track of what are called "selections" which refers to packages that are installed, partially installed, have been remove, have been purged (there is a difference fro

Because of this "state information" you're able to take "snapshops" (sans version information) of your installed software, allowing you to move from one set of installed software to another with a few simple commands.  The only feature missing from dpkg/apt/etc that I found useful in rpm is the rpm -v command to verify the installed files against what's installed by the package itself.

Packages that have been "removed" have the program files removed, but the configuration files are left in place.  This allows you to reinstall a package with your configuration already in place.  To purge a package also removes those configuration files. This is really the fault of package maintainers that do not remove these files in their postrm scripts.
